name: Kepler-1649
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-1649 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-1649 is a star with 0.2 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.23 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-1649 is known to have undefined exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-1649 system


Kepler-1649 b

Kepler-1649 b was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-1649 b is 1.0334999999999999 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-1649 b is 1.017 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-1649 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.


Kepler-1649 c

Kepler-1649 c was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-1649 c is 1.19886 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-1649 c is 1.06 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-1649 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars. With a mass of 1.19886 Earth masses and a semi-major axis of 0.0649 astronomical units, Kepler-1649 c could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-1649, which contains undefined planets and was discovered by undefined.
